content.text: Measure and record the diameter \(d\) of the short sample of wire that is attached to the card. You may remove the wire from the card
Calculate the cross-sectional area \(A\) of the wire, in \(\text{m}^2\), using the formula
Use the wire attached to the metre rule, one of the voltmeters and one of the resistors to set up the partial circuit shown in Fig. 1.1
There are two crocodile clips, one labelled K and the other labelled L
Place K and L so that the distance \(l\) between them is approximately \(30 \text{cm}\)
Measure and record the distance \(l\) between K and L
Use the other resistor and the other voltmeter to complete the circuit shown in Fig. 1.2
Place the crocodile clip M at a distance \(l\) from L
The value of \(l\) should be the same as in (b)(ii)
Switch on the power supply
Record the voltmeter readings \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\) as shown in Fig. 1.2
Switch off the power supply

Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1
The rods of the two clamps must be at the same height above the bench
Position the stands so that the rubber band has no slack
Measure and record the mass \(m\) of the mass hanger
Suspend the mass hanger from the centre of the lower part of the rubber band as shown in Fig. 2.2
Measure and record the angle \(\theta\) as shown in Fig. 2.2
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(\theta\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........

Calculate \(\tan^2 \frac{\theta}{2}\)

Measure and record the total mass \(m\) of the mass hanger and slotted mass
